Issue: Internet Connectivity Issue

Resolution:
Basic Checks:
Restart your modem and router: This can often resolve temporary glitches and improve performance. 
Assess the bandwidth: Use a bandwidth check tool to see if your connection is consistently slower than usual. 
Check for Wi-Fi signal strength: Ensured the device is close to the router and that the signal isn't being obstructed by thick walls or electronic devices. 
Use wired connections when possible: Tried Ethernet connections which generally more reliable and faster than Wi-Fi. 

Troubleshooting Steps:
Check for outages: If the problem is widespread, it could be an area outage. 
Scanned for malware: Malware can drain bandwidth and slow down your connection. 
Update firmware: Outdated firmware can cause performance issues and slow speeds. 
Contact your ISP: If the issue persists, your ISP can help diagnose and resolve problems on their end. 

Reduce background apps and processes: Close unnecessary programs and browser tabs to free up bandwidth. 
Cleared browser cache and history: This can improve browsing speed and reduce lag. 
Checked for signal interference: Wireless interference can affect Wi-Fi performance, so try changing your Wi-Fi channel or repositioning your router. 
Manage network congestion: If you have many devices connected, consider limiting usage during peak times or optimizing your network configuration. 


Advanced Troubleshooting:
Consider upgrading your router or ISP plan:
Older routers or low-bandwidth plans may not be sufficient for your needs. 
Use a VPN:
If you're experiencing throttling or network congestion, a VPN can help bypass these issues. 
Check your network settings:
Incorrect settings can cause connectivity problems, so reviewed your configuration.

Issue: Laptop Performance is too slow

Resolution:
1. Basic Checks and Restart:
Restart the computer: A simple restart can clear temporary files and refresh system resources, often resolving minor slowdowns.
Clean up your desktop: Too many shortcuts and files on your desktop can slow things down. 

2. Software and Drivers:
Update Windows and drivers: Ensure your operating system and device drivers are up to date, as outdated software can lead to performance issues. 
Check for software updates: Make sure all installed programs are updated, as updates often include performance improvements and bug fixes. 
Disabled or removed browser extensions: Excessive extensions can consume resources and slow down your browser. 

3. Disk Space and Memory:
Free up disk space:
Low disk space can significantly impact performance. Used Disk Cleanup or removed unnecessary files and programs. 
Manage startup programs:
Limit the number of programs that start automatically with Windows to reduce the load on the system. 
Check RAM usage:
If running many programs, ensure we have enough RAM to prevent slowdowns.

Issue_Description: Printer in Network - Unable to Print
Resolution_Notes:
Issue: Printer in Network - Unable to Print

Resolution:
Network Configuration:
IP Address: Confirmed the printer has a valid IP address and that it's on the same network as the devices. Access the printer's web interface or control panel to check its IP address. 
Ping Test: Use the ping command in a terminal window to verify communication with the printer by its IP address. 
Firewall: Ensure that firewalls on your computer or router are not blocking communication to the printer. 

Printer Settings:
Driver: Made sure user have the correct printer driver installed on your computer. 
Print Queue: Checked the print queue on your computer for any stuck or corrupted print jobs. 
Default Printer: Verified that the printer is set as the default printer on your computer. 
Web Interface: Checked the printer's web interface for any error messages or alerts. 


Advanced Troubleshooting:
Static IP: If the printer frequently loses its IP address, consider assigning it a static IP address. 
SNMP: If user having trouble with SNMP, ensured the required dependencies are installed and refer to your printer's documentation. 
Ports: Ensure that the necessary ports (161, 162, and 9100) are open through your firewall. 
Factory Reset: As a last resort, you can try a factory reset on the printer. 

Issue fixed.

1. Basic Checks:
Power Cycle: Turn off the printer, unplug it, wait 30 seconds, then plug it back in and turn it on. 
Restart Router: Unplug the router, wait 30 seconds, then plug it back in. 
Check Connections: Ensure the printer is securely connected to the network via Ethernet or Wi-Fi, and that the cables are properly plugged in. 

2. Network Configuration:
IP Address: Confirmed the printer has a valid IP address and that it's on the same network as the devices. Access the printer's web interface or control panel to check its IP address. 
Ping Test: Use the ping command in a terminal window to verify communication with the printer by its IP address. 
Firewall: Ensure that firewalls on your computer or router are not blocking communication to the printer. 

3. Printer Settings:
Driver: Made sure user have the correct printer driver installed on your computer. 
Print Queue: Checked the print queue on your computer for any stuck or corrupted print jobs. 
Default Printer: Verified that the printer is set as the default printer on your computer. 
Web Interface: Checked the printer's web interface for any error messages or alerts.

1. Basic Checks:
Physical Connection:
If using a wired mouse, ensure it's properly plugged into a USB port. Try different ports. 
Wireless Mouse:
If it's a wireless mouse, make sure it's turned on, the receiver is connected, and the batteries are good. 
Restart:
A simple restart of your laptop can often resolve minor glitches that might be preventing the mouse from working properly. 

2. Driver Issues:
Update Drivers:
Outdated or corrupted drivers can cause mouse problems. You can update the drivers through Device Manager. 
Reinstall Drivers:
If updating doesn't fix the issue, you can try reinstalling the drivers by uninstalling them in Device Manager and then restarting your computer. 
Bluetooth Issues:
If you're using a Bluetooth mouse, make sure your Bluetooth adapter is working, and the mouse is properly paired. You may need to update or reinstall the Bluetooth drivers.

Mouse worked.
Issue resolved.

Unable to connect or unable to print 

Detailed Troubleshooting Steps:
1.      1. Check for Error Lights and Messages:
Look for any error lights or messages displayed on the printer's control panel. 
2.      2. Clear the Print Queue:
If print jobs are stuck in the queue, clear them to see if the issue resolves itself.
3.      3. Restart the Print Spooler:
Restarting the Print Spooler service can resolve issues with printing queues 
4.      4. Solidify the Connection:
Ensure your printer is properly connected to your computer via cable or Wi-Fi. 
5.      5. Verify Printer Selection:
Make sure you've selected the correct printer in your software or operating system settings. 
6.      6. Check Paper and Ink:
Ensure there is sufficient paper in the tray and that ink cartridges (if applicable) are not empty or low, 
7.      7. Update or Reinstall Drivers:
Outdated or corrupted drivers can cause printing problems, so updating or reinstalling them may resolve the issue. 
8.      8. Test the Printer:
Try printing a test page to check if the printer is functioning correctly. 
9.      9. Hard Reset:
If the problem persists, try a hard reset of the printer by unplugging it for a few minutes. 

Able to print

Issue:  Enable the Pop-up Blocker

Trouble Shooting Steps:
1.      Open Internet Explorer: Launch the browser on your computer.
2.      Access Internet Options: Click on the "Tools" menu (or the gear icon) in the upper-right corner, then select "Internet Options,"
3.      Go to the Privacy Tab: In the Internet Options window, click on the "Privacy" tab.
4.      Enable the Pop-up Blocker: Under the "Pop-up Blocker" section, check the box that says "Turn on Pop-up Blocker".
5.      Confirm Changes: Click "OK" to save the settings and enable the pop-up blocker. 

Able to open the webpages without any issues.
